info18: 八丈 nenezu, nenezume, memizu；三根 meme zume；大賀郷 memezu, memezume；樫立 nenezume；中之郷 nenezume；末吉 mimizume
info19: PR *memezu C；佐仁 mëë̃dza；上嘉鉄 mimidaa；大和浜 mɨmɨdzɨ；諸鈍 mɨmɨt；与論 miːmidʑi；沖縄 mimizi；首里 mimidʑi；大神 mimikɯ；石垣 mimidzɨ；与那国 dimimi；PR *memezu；OR mimizu 61. *memezu (PR) 'earthworm': mimizjaa (志戸桶；mǝǝ̃za (佐仁；mǝǝza (名瀬；mïmïzï (大和浜、湯湾；mïmït (古仁屋；mïïza (伊仙；mïda (井之川；miminza (田皆；mimizi (奥、伊江島、首里；zïmizï (池間；mimigï (大神；miimazï (大浦；miMzï (与那覇；miimizï (上地；mimizï (中筋、波照間；mi(i)mizï (石垣；mimizu (大浜；mimicï (川平；miijazi (竹富；mimancï (小浜；miimazi (鳩間、黒島；miminci (祖納). The Amami forms ending in a probably had the diminutive suffix *wa. For some reason、伊江島 and 首里 do not have the expected final mora *z̧i、and 竹富、lacking *zï、shares this development. The *mi(i)mazï version was probably a Sakishima innovation. The 池間 form is hard to explain. In medieval Japanese 'earthworm' was mimizu、but it is memezu in Hachijo and in Kyusfu (Kumamoto and Kagoshima). The missing OJ formmust have been *mi2mi2zu、perhaps from mi2 (OJ) 'to turn、go around,' a bigrade verb、and *su 'thing.' The JR word could have been *me2me2n(o2)su 'wriggler.' PR *memedu；伊江島 mimizi；首里 mimiʑaː；平良 mimizɿ；石垣 mimidzɨ；与那国 dimimi

info19: PR *mune A；喜界、北奄美大島、南奄美大島、坂峯 munï；国頭、今帰仁、沖縄、与論 nii；大神 mmi-fkɯ；；沖永良部、石垣、与那国 nni；徳之島 nïï；PR *mune 24. *mune (PR) 'breast、chest': muni (志戸桶、祖納；munɪ (阿伝；munï (名瀬、大和浜、湯湾；munï (古仁屋、諸鈍；niigucï (井之川；nɪɪ (亀津；nii (手々知名、瀬利覚、伊江島、与那嶺；niguci (茶花；inni (奥、辺土名；nni (那覇、石垣、大浜、川平、鳩間、黒島、与那国；nni ~ nniguci (首里；nmiucï (池間、佐良浜；nmifukï (大神；nmi (大浦；nmifucï (上地；Mnifucï (中筋；nni ~ nnuuci (竹富；minoocï (小浜；nicï (波照間). The longer forms have *kuti or *-guti (137) 'mouth' suffixed、from PR *muneguti 'solar plexus,' literally 'mouth (entry) to the breast.' The alternation *mune ~ *muna- (in compounds) shows that the JR word was *mune. In 小浜、minoocï < *munaguti. The 祖納 form must be a loanword from Amami or Japan. PR *mune；伊江島 niː；首里 nni；平良 mni；石垣 nni；与那国 nni A 北奄美 munï；南奄美 muni；瀬留 munï   PM *mni > Yonaha mni, but Kurima and Tarama nni and Hirara, Sawda, Ikema, Ōgami mmi ‘chest’.

info8: 高句驪 *wOsikam 烏斯含 e. OJ usagi 3.6 ‘hare’, cf. development of 3.6 to 2.5 in OJ pemi ‘snake’ above. Cf. 高句驪uryo *osigam ‘hare’. The last example brings us to an interesting internal issue. On the basis of 高句驪uryo *osigam we would expect that the pJ *usagi would belong to accent 13 Zdb lists siwam- as a consonantal verb. The examples, both in logographic script in OJ and in phonetic in MJ, provide no basis for conclusion that siwam- used to be a consonant rather than a vowel verb in OJ. The earliest known attestation of this verb is in the form siwabitarikeru ‘has wrinkled’ (Konjaku monogatari 26.2) that shows that it is either a consonantal or upper-bigrade vowel verb (Ohno 1990:695). 14 I am indebted to Blaine Erickson for pointing this out to me. class 3.7 (LHL-L) that correlates with accent class 2.5 (LH-L), but it belongs to accent class 3.6 (LHH-H), which correlates with 2.4 (LH-H). Furthermore, we have a number of cases where either a lack of accentual data or irregularity in accentuation could make a choice between 2.5 and 2.4 or 2.5 or 2.3 questionable, although the bulk of the evidence normally points to class 2.5 (cf., e.g., sake ‘salmon’ 2.5/2.3? or above-mentioned wosa ‘elder’ 2.5/2.4?). The same picture is typical for accent classes 3.6 and 3.7. This, in combination with the observation made above regarding the potential 高句驪uryo cognate *osigam for pJ *usagi 3.6, suggests a hypothesis that the small classes 2.5 and 3.7a/b became small by attrition: a number of words that used to belong to those classes are now found under 2.4, 2.3, and 3.6.15 There is one additional external comparison that could further support this attrition hypothesis: OJ asa ‘hemp’ 2.3 ~ MK sám ‘id.’. info10: 不明（常陸） OJ yuⁿduru-pa is MdJ yuzuri-ha (譲り葉, Daphniphyllum macropodum), a tall evergreen tree that grows in the wild or can be planted. It is widespread in central and southern Honshū, Kyūshū, and Shikoku. The name of the plant is derived from the fact that when new leaves appear in the spring, old leaves fall off, giving their place (yuⁿdur- ‘to hand over’) for the new leaves. Leaves of yuⁿduru-pa are fleshy and smooth, with the underside having a white color. It blooms in summer with small yellowish green flowers that turn into purple fruits. The bark and leaves are used for medicinal purposes, and leaves are used for New Year decorations, especially being attached to simenawa ‘sacred straw rope’ or kagami-moti ‘large rice cake offered to deities’ (Nakanishi 1985: 332; Mizushima 1986: 408). OJ yuⁿduru- is an expected reflex in compounds of pre- OJ *yuⁿdurï < PJN *yuⁿduruy. In bound and free form is the same: yuⁿduru due to the regular *-y loss.
